name: Kinda Sorta Sours
headline: Kinda Sorta Sours
keywords: Easy Snack Recipes,Make Ahead,American,Pickle Recipes,Cucumber,Onion Recipes,Celery,Gluten Free,Low-Fat,Vegan

recipeInstructions.text: Combine the onion and cucumber slices in a clean spring-top jar.
Combine the remaining ingredients, with the exception of the garlic, in a non-reactive saucepan. Bring to a boil and simmer for 4 full minutes to wake up the spice flavors.
Add the garlic cloves to the jar. Slowly and gently pour the pickling liquid over the onion and cucumber slices, filling to the top of the jar.
Cool to room temperature. Top off the pickles with any remaining pickling liquid and refrigerate.

review.reviewBody: They were really good.  Both the sour and sweet.
These were really good except mine were way too SALTY! Â Two TBL plus Two Tsp...didi anyone else have this and if so what you adjusted it too?
I have made these 4 times for family members. Should never opened that can of worms. Now they expect these wonderful 'crispies' at every meal.

I made these about a week ago and have already made them twice, give it a try, the best pickle recipe ever, I will never buy pickles again, easy and oh sooo good, thanks Alton (again you always come thru), I am going to try these using zucchini

OK, so here's the deal... I LOVE pickles. And I thought, what the heck, make these! I adjusted the recipe based on other's comments. Reduced sugar by half and added some fresh dill.

Yup...these are good. My husband was skeptical but he tasted one chip and pronounced it "excellent."

I couldn't find champagne vinegar but white wine vinegar worked great. Word to the wise: ADD FRESH DILL.

And cut these cucumbers thickly, not thinly!
Not sour at all and just plain to sweet. I like AB's programs his tastebud leave much to be desired...
Best pickles ever. I can never wait until they're actually ready before I start eating them.

This is  a good all around pickling recipe. My daughters just love it. I've even used it to pickle full jars of onions, carrots, sweet peppers, and habanero peppers, which are great paired with hamburgers.
This has become the favorite pickle for my family.
I've made these often, using cider as the only vinegar, and adding several fresh dill heads and leaves to the jar. It makes for an awesome dill pickle!

I will NEVER buy pickles from the store again! I just made these and while still hot, they are better than the store's. I didn't have champagne vinegar, but I had some red and white wine vinegars so that was used. Also didn't have mustard seeds so I used an extra teaspoon of pickling spice, which has mustard seeds in it anyway. I should have known that anything coming from Alton Brown was going to be worth trying. Thanks Alton :
These were fantastic and easy to make!!!!  I always double the recipe when I make them.

I love store bought pickles but my wife doesn't.  I've made these pickles for the last 2 years using garden grown cucumbers and I think they're fantastic!  The downside for me now is that my wife likes these and I don't get to eat as many as I used to!

I made 3 jars a few weeks ago, and I can't stop eating them, really good eats!

Now I need to see if I can do it with green tomatoes, any ideas?

Can't find real sour pickles in the grocery store any more.  I've made this recipe several times with wonderful results -- crispy, sour, tasty pickles which last a long time in the fridge. I usually add small boiling onions instead of the sliced onions.   As a fellow southerner to Alton, I am delighted to have a recipe which provides me with the taste from my childhood.
i  can't find anything.

Don't know if anyone answered you Tina or if you looked up the answer online.

You'd have to hot water or pressure can the pickles in a canner, with appropriate sealing jars (ie, not flip top bail lids) to put these up.

As presented, the recipe is for "refrigerator pickles" not "putting up pickles".

It would be easy enough to tweak the recipe, though.

I just love these pickles. I've made them twice this past week. I do have a question though, and hopefully someone reading the board has an answer. The recipe is written as a refrigerator recipe. Can I put these up using traditional canning methods so that they're good for a year and I don't have eight jars in my fridge (like I do right now)?
Another easy recipe from AB! This are great on burgers or just by themselves. I used them to make tuna salad too...

Saw the show last night and these pickles sounded interesting like one's my Mom use to make.  Anyone make them with regular vinegar instead of those listed?  I am allergic to apples and afraid to try them if they have to be made with cider vinegar?  I know our fav Alton mentioned with vinegars can be interchanged, but wondered if anyone did?

This recipe is ridiculously easy. I made a couple of different batches - the first one I did exactly according to the recipe and the second I used only half as much sugar. I thought they both turned out really well with no real significant difference in sweetness level, so going forward I will only use half the sugar. I am not a big sweet pickle fan so I wasn't sure I was going to like them but they don't taste super sweet, it's more of a background flavor. I taste the sour much more than the sweet.

Someone mentioned their pickles turned out mushy - mine were perfectly crisp but I was using very fresh cucumbers. Maybe if you get your cukes from the grocery store they may be a lot older and less able to hold their crispness. I recommend a) growing them yourself or b) getting them from the farmer's market (which is what I did).

I make these pickles all summer with local farm cucumbers.  I have even made them with the English cucumbers that come wrapped in plastic in the supermarket.  After eating these pickles, it's hard to go back to store-bought.  They are just that good.  Thank you, Alton, for a classic recipe.

I made these 2 weeks ago, so they are about as good as they are going to get.  I found them to be mushy and not really as sour as you would expect a pickle to be.  Just got a lukewarm response at the Thanksgiving snack table.  Probably will not make these again.  Firecrackers were great, though!
They are good for samwiches, but not really eating pickles.
I love these pickles. There easy to make and just plain good.
enough about these pickles.  I am a new viewer to Food Network and Mr. Brown - you are my favorite!
Too sweet. needs less sugar and more sour. Is the garlic supposed to turn blue?
I thought these looked like fun on TV so I tried them.  I was surprised by how good they are!  Next time I will slice the cukes thicker & use less vinegar.
Pickle making success at last.  These are good!!
This is one of the easiest recipe I've ever made. I'll have some in my fridge for the rest of the gardening season.
I've served these to guests a number of time, and always get requests for the recipe.  They are fantastic and easy to make.  I highly recommend them!

I just love these pickles and I am not alone.  I can barely keep these in the house!  Everyone I bring some to keeps asking when they can get more.  It is really an easy recipe, but I don't mind all the rave reviews (always giving recipe credit to Mr. Brown, of course).  I, myself, can't stop eating them once I start - they're highly addictive!  chinasmom2000
delightful!

video.name: Sweet Pickles and Sour Pickles
video.description: Alton shows how miniscule DNA alterations produce sweet and sour pickles.
